awd_titl_txt: Weaving Stability from Dissipation: Fixed-Point Engineering for Quantum Information Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how physical systems approach equilibrium is a central question in statistical physics, and this topic is all the more profound when systems behave according to the laws of quantum mechanics.   As a familiar example, consider how a hot cup of tea or a cold glass of water equilibrate to room temperature.  One cools down while the other warms up; but in each case individual molecular interactions affect the rate and the fluctuations with which these systems approach equilibrium.  A more nuanced example comes from the field of quantum computing, where information can be encoded in the quantum mechanical spin states of individual molecules.  One compelling motivation for this is to produce more powerful computers with memory and information processing capabilities far superior to today's classical computers.  However, since relaxation towards equilibrium can disorganize the quantum information stored in molecules, equilibration is normally considered an obstacle or a hindrance for quantum computing.  The goal of this project is to find ways to utilize the stability of states near equilibrium in order to improve quantum computing protocols.  Methods to characterize and influence the stability of multi-particle quantum states will be developed.  Techniques to "attract" or nudge any given initial state towards a set of stable equilibrium states that contain genuinely non-classical multi-particle correlations ("entanglement") needed for quantum computing will be explored.  This research will address fundamental questions about the conditions under which stabilization to a desired quantum state may be achieved, and it will expand the toolkit and of methods to characterize and control dissipative quantum systems.  This project also provides education and training for students working on subjects at the cross-disciplinary boundaries between quantum information science, quantum control theory, applied mathematics, and many-body and statistical physics.  

Over the last few years, the principal investigator has established rigorous conditions for a general quantum state of interest to be the unique fixed point of a class of continuous-time "frustration-free" Markovian dynamics, subject to realistic locality constraints. Building on these results, this project aims to explore quantum stabilization problems in physical settings that remain largely uncharted as yet -- for instance: (i) Continuous-time Markovian dynamics under more general constraints than imposed by locality, including sensitivity to perturbations and periodically time-varying Floquet-Markov generators; (ii) Constrained discrete-time Markovian dynamics, for which the intriguing possibilities of exact dissipative state preparation and dissipative encoding in finite time arise; (iii) Randomized open-system dynamics, which may shed light on the stabilizability properties of generic (random) target states or subspaces. The methods to be employed will be both analytical and numerical, and will draw on a diverse range of tools from applied mathematics and quantum control theory (including operator algebras, Lyapunov stability techniques, and semi-definite programming), to quantum information theory and many-body physics (notably, entanglement theory, information-preserving structures, and tensor-network techniques). Theoretically, a central theme will be to clarify the extent to which core features from many-body and statistical mechanics -- in particular, the complexity of quantum correlations in the equilibrium state, the lack of frustration, the gapped nature or the commutativity of the underlying "parent" Hamiltonians -- may be brought to bear on the feasibility and efficiency of stabilization tasks for quantum information processing.  From a practical standpoint, the goal of these investigations is to improve protocols for dissipative quantum state preparation and quantum information encoding.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how a physical system in contact with its surrounding environment converges to a steady state -- a "fixed point" that no longer changes in time (think of how a cup of hot coffee or a glass of cold beer eventually thermalize to room temperature) -- is a central question of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics. In the context of quantum information science, the ability to engineer the dissipative environment to which a system of interest couples can enable important tasks, that would not be achievable otherwise. For instance, one may design dissipative dynamics that "attracts" the system toward a steady state containing genuinely non-classical multi-particle correlations ("entanglement"), independent of the system's initial state; or, one may create "synthetic" phases of matter with exotic properties, that would not exist under ordinary conditions.

The overarching goal of this project has been to develop a general framework for characterizing and engineering dissipative quantum dynamics from a memoryless ("Markovian") environment, with emphasis on i) incorporating resource constraints that may restrict the allowable models and manipulations -- such as, spatial locality; and ii) addressing dynamical settings that have remained largely unexplored as yet -- such as, systems evolving under discrete-time sequences of dissipative quantum operations (akin to "dissipative quantum circuits"), or systems comprising indistinguishable quantum particles (fermions or bosons).

 A number of outcomes have emerged from the investigations supported by this award over its duration -- as summarized in thirteen research articles to date. The following highlights may serve to illustrate the breadth of our findings. 

  • Fundamental aspects of the problem of designing Markovian dynamics that admits a desired quantum state as its unique steady state, subject to the constraint that only a few "qubit" subsystems are affected by the dynamics at any given time, have been elucidated. Surprisingly, our analysis shows that quantum states that are unique, non-degenerate ground state of local Hamiltonians may fail to be "stabilizable" by dynamics obeying the same locality constraint.
  • A characterization of dissipative encoding protocols has been provided, whereby Markovian dissipative dynamics is used to transfer quantum information into a quantum code of interest, in ways that offer additional robustness against initialization errors as compared to non-dissipative schemes. In particular, for the important class of stabilizer quantum codes, discrete-time dissipative encoders that achieve the task in a finite number of steps have been constructed.
  • The emergence of novel, topologically non-trivial phases has been theoretically demonstrated for many-body systems of non-interacting bosons undergoing Markovian dissipation -- in stark contrast with equilibrium settings where such phases cannot provably exist. In close analogy to the Majorana fermions that are akin to "split electrons" and are predicted to exist in certain superconducting systems, split bosonic degree of freedom -- Majorana bosons -- are now predicted to emerge in dissipative bosonic systems under appropriate conditions.

Altogether, the results emerged from this project have thus contributed to advance the cross-disciplinary knowledge frontier of dissipative quantum engineering and many-body quantum systems.

In addition to its intellectual merit, and despite the extra challenges posed by the COVID pandemic during the last two years, the project has throughout incorporated strong educational and outreach components. A total of four graduate students (two of them being women) have been partly supported by this award and engaged in research at different stages, under the direct supervision by the principal investigator. All these students have received intensive training on subjects at the boundary between quantum information processing, dynamical system theory, applied mathematics, and many-body physics -- making them well-prepared for the increasingly cross-disciplinary demands of today's careers in quantum science and technology. The principal investigator has further contributed to disseminate knowledge and generate excitement in quantum science by delivering both (in-person and virtual) technical and non-technical presentations at conferences and universities, as well as by teaching dedicated courses at the undergraduate and graduate level.
